section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, sing a push/pull song, and introduce vocabulary (push, pull).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What things can move with a push?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use category words; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Make connections between situations.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show children picture cards of different items that they can move by pushing or pulling.
Have children sort the items into a “Push” and a “Pull” pile.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we make things go?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is being pushed or pulled in your book?
Pretend you are trying to move something that’s very heavy.
Can you find something in the classroom that moves fast?
Draw a picture of something that moves slow.
What makes something easy to move?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the words push and pull? Can you say a word that begins with that letter?
Can you use blocks to make something that is easy to push?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Copyright © 2019 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder make connections and introduce vocabulary (push and pull, connect).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Push and Pull.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use category words; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Make connections between situations.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children play with toy cars to find different ways they can make the cars move.
Have children observe ways to speed up, slow down, stop, and change the direction of their toy cars.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we make things go?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show something in a book that you could pull to move?
Show how you would lift something that is heavy.
Can you find three things in the room that are easy to move?
Can you draw a picture of something that moves very fast?
Can you make a big wave in the ocean?
Can you push three letters together to make the word cat?
Can you make a rocket out of blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Copyright © 2019 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Richard Peterson/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Use Background Knowledge and introduce vocabulary (muscles, shopping cart).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Push and Pull and asking the guiding question, What things can move with a pull?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use category words; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Make connections between situations.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review with children pictures of moving people, animals, and objects and talk about how fast or slow they are moving.
Have children sort the cards by slow and fast.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we make things go?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which characters in the book move fast? Which move slow?
Pretend you are doing everything really slow.
Compare how fast two different-sized balls fall to the ground.
Draw a picture of a fast animal.
What animal moves slow? Can you draw it?
What letter makes the sound that you hear at the beginning of the word speed?
Can you build a really fast car out of blocks? How will you show that it’s really fast?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Copyright © 2019 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Great Big Enormous Yuca

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about how things move and introduce vocabulary words (pull, enormous).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts The Great Big Enormous Yuca and Push and Pull.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, How can we make things move?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use category words; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Make connections between situations.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show children picture cards and have them decide whether they can move what is shown.
Have children offer strategies for moving the objects they cannot move.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we make things go?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a character in the book who can move very fast?
Pretend you are moving like a cat. How fast or slow would you move?
Can you put five animals in order from slowest to fastest?
Draw the enormous yuca after it was pulled from the ground.
Can you create a story about the people who helped the old man pull the yuca out of the ground?
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning sound you hear in the word yuca? What other word begins with the same sound?
Can you build something enormous out of blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Copyright © 2019 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time for a movement activity and introduce vocabulary (machines, motion).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What can happen when something is moving?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Make connections between situations.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Use different art materials for exploration and sensory experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: If you had to move a large object, what would it be and how would you move it?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we make things go?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What animals are fast? What animals are slow?
Pretend you are carrying a really heavy box.
See how fast you can make toy cars go.
Make up a story where everything moves backwards, and draw a picture of it.
Can you imagine a machine that helps you jump really high? Can you draw it?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word fast?
Can you build a ramp out of blocks for toy cars?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Copyright © 2019 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Make connections between situations.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Make connections between situations.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Make connections between situations.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Make connections between situations.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Make connections between situations.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
